abstract:
**Abstract**  
• We investigate the computability of Sinai-Ruelle-Bowen (SRB) measures in quadratic maps $f_a(x) = ax(1-x)$  
• Demonstrate the existence of computable parameters $a \in (0,4)$ with non-computable SRB measures  
• Challenge the efficacy of Monte Carlo methods for statistical predictions in chaotic systems  

**Introduction**  
• Dynamical systems often exhibit chaotic behavior, limiting deterministic predictions  
• Monte Carlo methods rely on statistical averaging but fail for certain computable systems  
• Focus on quadratic maps as prototypical examples of nonlinear dynamics  

**Related Work**  
• Prior studies on computability of invariant measures in symbolic and Hamiltonian systems  
• Non-computability results in continuous maps of the circle [GHR10]  
• Computational complexity of attractors in quadratic families [RY19]  

**Methodology**  
• Construct admissible parameters using Johnson’s technique [Joh87]  
• Employ Wasserstein-Kantorovich distance $W_1$ to quantify measure convergence  
• Leverage symbolic dynamics on Cantor sets $C_a$ for periodic orbit control  

**Experiment**  
• Algorithmically generate parabolic parameters $a_k$ with nested intervals $I_k$  
• Verify weak convergence of empirical measures $\nu_{a_k}^n$ to non-computable limits  
• Quantify approximation errors $|\nu_{a_k}^m(\text{Per}(n)) - l_n^k| < 2^{-k}$  

**Conclusion**  
• Established existence of computable maps with non-computable SRB measures  
• Demonstrated fundamental limitations of numerical statistical methods  
• Open questions remain about prevalence in higher-dimensional systems
